I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based grant to Nepal for the School Sector Program. The report also describes proposed 
technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Development for School Sector Program Implementation, 
and if the Board approves the proposed grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by 
the Board, will approve the TA.1  
 
2.  The program is a follow-on to the ongoing Education Sector Program, subprogram III,2 
which supports the Government of Nepal's 7-year (FY2010–FY2016) School Sector Reform 
Program (SSRP). The SSRP is supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and eight 
other  development  partners3  using  the  sector-wide  approach  (SWAp).  Building  on  the 
achievements of the Education for All Program (2004–2009), the SSRP aims to (i) expand 
access  and  equity,  (ii)  improve  quality  and  relevance,  and  (iii)  strengthen  the  institutional 
capacity of the entire school education system. The Education Sector Program, subprogram III 
supported the first 3 years of SSRP implementation, and this program will continue to support it 
during  FY2012–FY2014.  It  will  contribute  to  Nepal’s  long-term  economic  and  social 
development through an equitable, efficient, and relevant education system. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Nepal is undergoing major change, mainly emanating from deep political changes over 
the past two decades. This, in turn, is significantly impacting social transformation—the clearest 
manifestation of which is evident in the education sector, with rapid progress in participation and 
gender parity in school education. The sector may be characterized as having high demand, but 
investments have a long gestation period. The SSRP and this program must be viewed in this 
context. When the SSRP was designed (in the aftermath of the decade-long conflict), there was 
a high level of optimism. But the protracted peace and constitutional drafting process and 
frequent changes in government have made full implementation of the SSRP challenging.  
  
4.  Improving  equitable  access  to quality  education  is  accorded  the  highest  priority  on 
Nepal’s development agenda. Despite the challenging environment, successive governments 
have shown a strong commitment to implementing the SSRP, which is reflected in the periodic 
development plans as well as government spending for education. In the first 2 years of SSRP 
implementation,  substantial  progress  has  been  made  in  creating  an  enabling  policy 
environment.  The  government  has  approved  policies  for  free  basic  education,  minimum 
enabling  conditions  (MECs)  for  student  learning,  curriculum  reforms,  teacher  minimum 
qualification upgrading and equitable deployment, and capacity development at the district and 
school levels. The new basic education cycle (grades 1–8) is in place and piloting of the new 
secondary education cycle (grades 9-12) has been initiated in five districts. 
 
5.  Impressive progress has been made in sector performance, particularly in access to 
education. Currently, about 95% of children have access to a primary school within 30 minutes’

walking distance. In 2010, (i) the net enrollment rate (NER) in primary education reached 95%, 
and Nepal is on track to meet Millennium Development Goal 2 (achieving universal primary 
education by 2015); (ii) the NER in basic education reached 86% and in secondary education 
27%; (iii) the share of grade 1 entrants with early childhood education and development (ECED) 
experience was 52%; (iv) the percentage of fully trained teachers was 77% at the basic and 
74% at the secondary levels; and (v) literacy programs benefited 2.8 million participants in 
2008–2010. Good progress was also evident in gender equity and social inclusion (GESI): (i) 
the gender parity index in NER reached 0.98 at all levels of primary and secondary education; 
(ii) the literacy rate of the 15+ age group reached 60% and its gender parity index 0.92; and (iii) 
shares of (a) Dalit (so-called untouchable caste) students (as a percentage of total enrollment) 
reached  18%  in  ECED,  20%  in  basic  and  9%  in  secondary  education;  and  (b)  Janajati 
(indigenous peoples) students 39% in ECED, 39% in basic and 38% in secondary education, 
both roughly in line with their share in the general population.4 
 
6.  The  progress  in  school  education  demonstrates  the  resilience  built  up  through 
incremental but critical reforms. This resilience stems mainly from the decentralized school 
system, which is a unique feature and strength of the education system in Nepal. However, 
rapid  expansion  in  access  has  underscored  the  urgency  of  ensuring  commensurate 
improvements in quality, efficiency, and institutional capacity to manage an expanded and 
inclusive school system. In particular, the school sector faces continuing challenges in: (i) 
providing quality basic education to hard-to-reach children from disadvantaged groups and 
areas; (ii)  ensuring  a  high quality  of  education;  (iii)  creating  an  enabling  and  safe  school 
environment; (iv) implementing an effective teacher management and professional development 
system;  and  (v)  strengthening  procurement,  financial  management,  and  monitoring  and 
evaluation (M&E) capacity. 
 
7.  The  lessons  from  the  Education  Sector  Program,  and  noted  in  2009  ADB  country 
assistance performance evaluation,5 indicate that (i) difficult reforms are feasible even during a 
fragile political transition, through sustained support to the decentralized school system with 
school-level  management  capacity  development;  (ii)  a  mature  SWAp  demonstrates  that 
sustained support to country systems enhances overall capacity of the government, including 
stronger program leadership and ownership; (iii) enhancing quality and efficiency in a rapidly 
expanding system requires improvements in M&E and data quality to produce the desired 
results; (iv) equitable improvements in student learning outcomes, particularly for disadvantaged 
children, require an integrated system-wide approach to GESI and investments in implementing 
MECs; and (v) the capacity of relevant central and local bodies must be enhanced to strengthen 
internal control mechanisms to improve transparency and mitigate fiduciary risks. 
 
8.  The program will build on these achievements and lessons by sharpening the focus on 
implementation of key policy reforms, including: (i) customized strategies for reaching out-of-
school children; (ii) enhancing student learning through meeting the MECs and assessment 
reforms; (iii) improving the safety of school buildings; (iv) strengthening the teaching force 
through better management, qualification upgrading, and increasing representation of women 
and  excluded  social  groups;  and (v)  strengthening  institutional  capacity for  effective  M&E, 
financial management, internal control and compliance, safeguards, and GESI implementation. 
                                                      
4  Further information on sector performance is in Sector Assessment (Summary): Education (accessible from the list 
of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
5  ADB. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Nepal—Delivering Assistance in a Challenging Environment.

3 
The program will also make necessary adjustments, including: (i) re-costing and revising the 
SSRP financial plan for FY2012–FY2014, (ii) assessing the fiduciary risks and incorporating 
additional mitigating measures, (iii) updating the gender and vulnerable communities action plan 
(GVCAP)6 for coherent implementation throughout the entire system, and (iv) updating the 
environmental management framework. 
 
9.  The program will support the SSRP in accordance with the provisions set forth in the 
Joint Financing Arrangement (JFA)7 mutually agreed upon by the government and development 
partners. To ensure SSRP implementation as envisaged, the program has developed a number 
of policy conditions with which the government must fully comply to receive the grant. In view of 
the pooled funding, the government and development partners follow a common SSRP results 
framework with agreed targets and performance indicators as summarized in the program 
design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). Some of these targets and indicators may be 
revised during the joint midterm review of SSRP in early 2012. 
 
10.  The program has four special features: 
 
(i)  Stronger focus on gender, social inclusion, and quality. The program will focus 
on equity and quality, and reinforce efforts to extend quality education to girls and 
children from vulnerable communities who are deprived as a result of gender and 
socioeconomic  factors.  These  efforts  comprise  incentives  that  target  individuals 
(scholarships and incentives to needy students) and institutions (MECs to the most 
disadvantaged basic education schools). 
(ii)  Strengthened  institutional  capacity  and  fiduciary  risk  management.  The 
capacity of the Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Department of Education (DOE) 
to implement the program effectively is critical for program success, and requires 
effective  and  transparent  financial  management.  The  program  will  strengthen 
institutional capacity with a focus on program management, procurement, financial 
management, and reporting systems, thereby helping mitigate fiduciary risks. 
(iii)  Greater focus on monitoring and evaluation. Good policy outcomes require policy 
making based on a robust understanding of what works and why. To achieve desired 
results  and  address  governance  risks,  the  program  will  focus  on  establishing 
stronger  M&E  protocols.  Independent  validation  of  the  government’s  education 
management information system data will be undertaken, particularly in the areas of 
enrollments, textbook and scholarship distribution, and identification of schools for 
targeted support. This will enable evidence-based interventions for high quality and 
inclusive education. 
(iv)  Innovative support for school safety. School buildings in Nepal are susceptible to 
multiple hazards, such as earthquake, landslide, flood and storm, and those arising 
from  climate  change.  The  program  will  support  school  safety  as  an  essential 
component of an enabling environment for student learning, a first for the education 
sector in Nepal.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impact  of  the  SSRP  will  be  enhanced  educational  attainment  and  livelihoods, 
particularly for girls and disadvantaged groups. The outcome will be increased access to and 
improved  quality  of  school  education,  particularly  basic  education,  especially  for  girls  and 
children from disadvantaged groups. The program will support the SSRP, and its expected 
impact and outcome will be consistent with the impact and outcome of the SSRP. 
 
C.  Outputs 
12.  The program is composed of five crosscutting outputs: (i) more equitable access to 
quality education, (ii) enhanced student learning, (iii) safer schools, (iv) enhanced teacher 
management  and  development,  and  (v)  better  management  of  governance  risks  in  the 
education sector. Social inclusion and quality are key objectives across the outputs. 
 
13.  Output 1: More equitable access to quality education. Despite substantial progress 
in expanding access to education, there are gaps in reaching the remaining out-of-school 
children in basic education, and retaining those in school. The program will support: (i) 
identification of out-of-school children and development of customized interventions to bring 
them into schools; (ii) scholarships and other basic and secondary  education incentives 
annually  for  more  than  3.8  million  girls  and  children  from  vulnerable  communities;  (iii) 
expansion of ECED provision in poverty areas; and (iv) construction and rehabilitation of 
classrooms and facilities in targeted schools to better serve disadvantaged students, especially 
girls and students with disabilities. This output will help achieve the government’s objective of a 
more  inclusive  education  system.  Two  tranche  release  conditions  (TRCs)  are  included  to 
implement strategic interventions to bring the out-of-school children to basic education schools. 
 
14.  Output 2: Enhanced student learning. The program will support quality improvement 
at the levels of inputs and processes. In terms of inputs, it will support government initiatives to: 
(i) ensure that all students receive the full set of textbooks within 2 weeks of the start of the 
academic year, (ii) increase the percentage of new entrants in grade 1 with ECED experience, 
and (iii) implement MECs in the most deprived basic education schools. The program has 
identified five priority MECs: provision of adequate numbers of classrooms, separate toilets for 
girls and boys, textbooks, learning materials and/or book corners, and adequate teachers based 
on the standard student–teacher ratio (40:1). With respect to processes, it will support SSRP 
initiatives to: (i) conduct the national assessment of student achievement for grades 3, 5, and 8; 
(ii) implement a continuous assessment system in the early grades; and (iii) scale up the 
provision of multilingual education. The five TRCs in this output emphasize the implementation 
of priority MECs in needy schools, and national assessment of student achievement. 
 
15.  Output 3: Safer schools. The program will help improve school safety, especially in 
densely populated areas, through: (i) vulnerability assessments; (ii) retrofitting and/or rebuilding 
of schools; (iii) providing training to teachers and students on best school safety practices; and 
(iv) training for masons, engineers and sub-engineers in construction of safe schools. The three 
TRCs in this output will require MOE to approve and implement the pilot school safety action 
plan and approve the comprehensive school safety action plan.  
  
16.  Output 4: Enhanced teacher management and development. A well-managed and 
qualified teaching force with role models for disadvantaged students is an essential component 
of quality improvement. The program will support government initiatives to: (i) enhance the 
qualification upgrading of basic school teachers; (ii) redeploy teachers based on the standard

5 
student–teacher ratio; and (iii) increase the proportional share of female, and Dalit and Janajati 
teachers as per the teacher service commission regulations. Decentralization poses significant 
challenges  for  teacher  management,  and  the  program  will  also  support  the  design  and 
implementation by the government of an effective teacher management system. The four TRCs 
in this output require MOE to (i) upgrade the academic qualifications of 7,000 teachers; and (ii) 
devise and implement an action plan for effective teacher management. 
 
17.  Output 5: Better management of governance risks in the education sector. The 
program  will  support  the  government  to  improve  financial  management  and  procurement 
through initiatives to: (i) investigate and take appropriate actions on audit observations; (ii) 
institute a payroll system to disburse teachers’ salaries through bank accounts; (iii) undertake 
tracking survey to check the flow of funds, particularly in the areas of textbooks, scholarships, 
and per capita funds; (iv) provide procurement training to the relevant staff in accordance with 
the provisions in the amended Public Procurement Regulations; and (v) implement simplified 
accounting procedures and financial management training in all schools. The program will also 
strengthen  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation  through  initiatives  to:  (i)  improve  social 
accountability mechanisms; (ii) strengthen program implementation arrangements; (iii) enhance 
M&E, and educational and financial management information systems; and (iv) establish an 
incentive mechanism to promote good practices and innovations in the sector. The nine TRCs in 
this output will help strengthen the management of governance risks in these two areas. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
18.  The revised estimated total cost for the SSRP for FY2012–FY2014 is $2,705.8 million 
which includes all recurrent and investment costs (Table 1). This amount is 57% higher than 
what was originally estimated in 2009 for the same period. This is mainly due to faster than 
expected  enrollment  growth,  significant  inflationary  pressures,  teacher  salary  adjustments, 
expansion of the scholarship program, and the provision of free textbooks up to grade 10 
(instead of grade 8). The currently projected available funding over the same period is estimated 
at  $2,365  million,  leaving  a  financing  gap  of  $340.9  million,  excluding  ADB’s  proposed 
assistance. This gap starts in FY2012, increasing substantially thereafter over the next 2 years.8 
 
19.  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $65,000,000 from ADB's Special 
Funds resources to help finance the program. With this grant, the total ADB support to the 
SSRP in FY2010–FY2014 will be $160 million. The terms and conditions for the grant will be as 
set forth in the draft grant agreement.9 The size of the ADB grant has been determined based 
on the overall estimated cost of SSRP, the amount the government plans to allocate (defined by 
its  fiscal  space  and  the  Medium  Term  Expenditure  Framework),  ADB’s  overall  assistance 
program to Nepal, and the pledged contribution from other development partners (as specified 
in the agreements signed with Ministry of Finance to date). Given the SWAp modality, the 
resources from development partners and the government are pooled and then allocated to 
competing needs in the sector. A significant portion of the ADB funding will be spent on 
textbooks, physical infrastructure, scholarships, and teacher management and development 
(these areas represent the largest share of SSRP spending). ADB assistance through the 
program will narrow the financing gap from $340.9 million (12.6%) to $275.9 million (10.2%).  
 
20.  The government is confident that it will be able to secure additional donor funding and 
increase its own share to finance the gap. The World Bank is considering an additional grant of

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  Program management. MOE will be executing agency and DOE will be implementing 
agency. The program will follow the program management arrangements specified in the JFA 
for SSRP. The JFA details the responsibilities of the government and the development partners, 
the  funding  mechanism,  procurement,  reporting,  monitoring  and  auditing,  and  other 
administrative requirements. The development partners meet regularly to review the financial 
status and implementation progress of the SSRP, and to commit and disburse funds. The 
program  will  focus  on  establishing  stronger  M&E  protocols,  strengthening  fiduciary  risk 
management,  enhancing  results-based  consultative  decision  making  processes,  and 
implementation of the governance and accountability action plan, and recommendations of the  
performance audits. 
 
22.  While  the  government  has  demonstrated  a  readiness  to  address  reported  financial 
irregularities during the first 2 years of SSRP implementation, its efforts have not been fully 
effective. This is primarily because of weak coordination and low capacity among MOE, DOE, 
district education offices, and schools. As a result, the DOE has not been able to monitor district 
and school level expenditures and submit timely financial management reports (FMRs). Hence, 
in addition to the measures described in output 5 (para. 17), the program will strengthen 
coordination  between  the  central  and  local  levels,  and  enhance  their  capacity  to  improve 
program management.  
 
23.  Implementation period. The program will support the SSRP from January 2012 to July 
2014. The expected completion date will be 15 July 2014 and closing date 31 December 2014. 
 
24.  Disbursement arrangements. ADB disbursements to the government will depend on 
the  government  fulfilling  the  tranche  release  conditions  as  outlined  in  the  Policy  Matrix 
(Appendix 4). The disbursements will be made in three tranches: a first tranche of $10 million in

7 
February 2012, a second tranche of $35 million in December 2012, and a third tranche of $20 
million in December 2013. The proceeds of the grant will be disbursed to the Ministry of Finance 
as the recipient in accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement 
Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.10 The grant proceeds will be used to 
finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and 
procured in ADB member countries, excluding ineligible items11 and imports financed by other 
bilateral and multilateral sources. No supporting import documentation will be required if, during 
each year that policy-based grant proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of total 
imports minus imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed 
under  other  official  development  assistance  is  greater  than  the  amount  expected  to  be 
disbursed  during  that  year.  The  government  will  submit  with  each  withdrawal  request  a 
certification confirming the government’s compliance with the above formula in respect of the 
period covered by the withdrawal request. 
 
25.  All withdrawals from the grant account will be deposited in the pooled foreign currency 
account (FCA) of the government established at the Nepal Rastra Bank. Under the JFA, the 
development partners have agreed to use the existing government system for disbursement and 
accounting  of  the  pooled  government  and  development  partner  funds.  MOE  will  use  the 
government’s reporting system to submit the FMR to the pooling development partners each 
trimester. Reimbursement of the funds from the FCA to the government’s consolidated account 
will be  contingent upon timely and accurate submission of the actual expenditures through the 
FMR. The funds from the FCA will be transferred to the government’s consolidated fund only 
upon the approval of the FMR by the pooling development partners. 
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
26.  Capacity development TA will be provided to MOE and DOE to assist them in effectively 
implementing the program. Support will be provided for (i) data analysis; (ii) student learning 
assessment; (iii) teacher development; (iv) institutional capacity enhancement (in the areas of 
financial management, public expenditure tracking survey, procurement training, institutional 
analysis, M&E, and social accountability mechanisms); and (v) program management.12 
 
27.  The government has requested ADB to finance, on a grant basis, TA for $500,000 
equivalent  to  be  funded  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office, domestic 
transportation, communication, and administrative support. The TA will commence in January 
2012 and end in July 2014, and require 4 person-months of international and 37 person-months 
of national consulting services. Consultants will be recruited individually and through a national 
firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time); TA disbursement will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
28.  Economic viability. Three direct benefits resulting from the program can be identified: 
(i) an average 5% increase in the annual earnings of workers with 8 years of basic education; 
(ii) increased worker productivity; and (iii) improved internal efficiency and reduced educational 
wastage, including a reduction in the number of student years required to complete basic 
education, from 11.5 to 9.7.13 In addition, a number of indirect benefits can be expected that are 
difficult to quantify, including improved health and sanitation outcomes, improved agricultural 
productivity, and more informed civic participation. 
 
29.  Fiscal sustainability. The sustainability of SSRP will depend primarily on two factors: 
(i) the ability of the government to allocate adequate budget to the education sector over time, 
and (ii) improvements in efficiency in the education sector as envisaged. As elaborated in the 
Economic and Financial Analysis,13 the government’s fiscal position is expected to improve in 
the coming years. The much-anticipated conclusion of the protracted peace process and a 
gradual improvement in the business climate will likely put Nepal on a sustained higher growth 
trajectory. These positive changes, coupled with the various tax reform initiatives to expand the 
tax base and eliminate leakages in collection, will create additional fiscal space over time 
enabling the government to increase the share of education spending in the total budget from 
16.3%  in  FY2010  to  19.8%  by  FY2016,  which  will  be  close  to  the  Fast  Track  Initiative’s 
indicative target of 20%. The efficiency gains expected to accrue to Nepal’s education sector as 
a result of the reforms being supported by SSRP including restructuring of the school system, 
improved financial management, and strengthened performance monitoring and evaluation will 
also keep costs down while improving overall education outcomes. This will in turn help in 
reinforcing the long-term fiscal sustainability of Nepal’s education sector. 
 
B.  Governance 
30.  Program-specific governance risks have been analyzed in line with the requirements of 
ADB's  Second  Governance  and  Anticorruption  Action  Plan.14  The  national  public  financial 
management (PFM) system is generally well designed but unevenly implemented. There have 
been significant recent improvements in the public procurement system. For example, the 
Procurement Act, 2007 and the establishment of the Public Procurement Monitoring Office 
under the Office of the Prime Minister and Council of Ministers have given direction for more 
effective procurement management, but require capacity enhancement and further reforms to 
minimize fiduciary risks. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained 
to and discussed with the government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, 
accountability and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
31.  Poverty incidence in Nepal has dropped to 25% in 2010 from 31% in 2005,15 but the 
drop is less dramatic for vulnerable groups. The program will target disadvantaged groups and 
poverty areas in (i) provision of education of an acceptable quality, (ii) scholarships provision,

(iii) ECED coverage, (iv) promotion of education in mother-tongue up to grade 3, (v) provision of 
midday meals, and (vi) recruitment of teachers from excluded groups.16 
 
32.  Gender and development. Gender parity in NER reached 0.98 in primary, basic, and 
secondary education in 2010, showing the contribution of SSRP in achieving gender equity in 
access. However, efforts are required to improve retention and completion rates, and education 
outcomes for girls. Further, the share of women in the teaching force remains low. A GVCAP 
has been developed to promote GESI across the system. Women’s participation in teaching will 
be increased as a result of the reservation policy introduced in January 2011, and through a 
government  action  plan  to  encourage  admission  of  underrepresented  groups  in  teachers 
colleges, and recruit and upgrade qualifications of under-qualified teachers from these groups. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
33.  Environment.  The  program  falls  into  environmental  category  B.  An  environmental 
assessment of the policy interventions shows that the construction and operation of school 
infrastructure  may  have  some  minor  impacts  on  the  environment,  all  of  which  can  be 
mitigated.17  The  government  follows  the  National  Environmental  Guidelines  for  School 
Improvement and Facility Management for site selection, design, and monitoring construction of 
school building and sanitation facilities. The guidelines also follow the National Building Code, 
which  aims  to  ensure  buildings  are  earthquake  safe.  The  program  has  prepared  an 
environmental management framework to ensure compliance with environmental safeguards. 
 
34.  Involuntary resettlement. The program falls into involuntary resettlement category C. 
There  will  be  no  involuntary  land  acquisition  or  resettlement.  Land for  school  buildings,  if 
required, will be acquired only through either voluntary donation, or a willing buyer–willing seller 
approach. A framework is in place to (i) establish voluntary donation and willing buyer–willing 
seller procedures, including record keeping of the process and relevant information disclosure; 
and (ii) ensure that the government will follow the stipulated approach.18 
 
35.  Indigenous peoples. The program falls into indigenous peoples category B because it 
will have a positive impact on indigenous peoples, who are the direct program beneficiaries. 
Nepal currently has 59 officially recognized Janajati groups (indigenous peoples) that together 
make up about 38% of the population. A separate indigenous peoples’ plan has not been 
prepared as indigenous peoples constitute the majority of program beneficiaries. The elements 
of an indigenous peoples’ plan are included in the overall program design, with affirmative 
action in teacher recruitment, scholarship provision, multilingual education, and ECED provision. 
Indigenous peoples communities were consulted during the SSRP appraisal, and the GVCAP 
ensures that they are beneficiaries of program implementation. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
36.  Political risks. The challenging security situation in some parts of the country makes 
it difficult to deliver educational services, and the program uses a peace building tool to help 
improve children’s access to education in these areas.19 Moreover, delays in writing the new 
constitution have affected the approval of amendments to the Education Act, which in turn has 
affected  initiatives  to  formalize  secondary  education  restructuring.  Nonetheless,  while  the

the  reforms  in  an  incremental  manner  and  preparing  the  groundwork  for  full-scale 
implementation once the required legislation is enacted. 
 
37.  Macroeconomic risks. Macroeconomic stability and sustained economic growth are 
key to the government’s ability to allocate sufficient resources to education. The government has 
reasonably maintained macroeconomic stability despite various challenges. Due to slower-than-
expected economic growth, continued support from development partners is essential to finance 
and sustain program implementation. Macroeconomic risks are minimal as both government 
and development partners have continued to accord high priority to education sector reforms. 
 
38.  Governance, including fiduciary, risks. An assessment undertaken by ADB indicates 
that the program faces significant fiduciary risks.20 While a sound financial management policy 
is in place, and there are increased fund flows to local bodies in line with Nepal’s strength in 
community involvement, risks include those that arise from the absence of elected local bodies, 
a  rigorous  M&E  protocol,  publicly  available  program-related  information,  and  financial 
management capacity. The risks and mitigation measures identified concern improving financial 
management  and  procurement,  monitoring  expenditures  and  performance,  strengthening 
capacity and internal control as well as compliance mechanisms so that audit irregularities are 
addressed and school management committees receive targeted support.21 The government 
has  committed  to  address  financial  management  issues  by  preparing  an  action  plan  and 
implementing it with immediate effect. ADB will provide TA to implement this action plan, which 
will complement the World Bank’s oversight function for fiduciary risk management. Macro-level 
steps are also being taken to mitigate systemic risks in PFM, procurement, and corruption. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
39.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, PFM, audits, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the JFA and grant documents. The government has agreed with ADB on the covenants for 
the program, which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board approve the grant not exceeding $65,000,000 to Nepal for the School Sector Program 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board.
